name: Udaipur
fun_fact: Fun fact: The Lake Palace of Udaipur, seemingly floating on Lake Pichola, inspired the design of the Taj Mahal. When Mughal emperor Shah Jahan rebelled against his father, he hid in Udaipur's Jag Mandir palace - and the palace's impressive architecture later influenced his creation of the Taj Mahal. Udaipur is called the 'Venice of the East' for its interconnected lakes, and was founded in 1553 by Maharana Udai Singh II as the new capital of the Mewar Kingdom.

hero_dishes.name: Dal Baati Churma
hero_dishes.description: The holy trinity of Rajasthani cuisine: golden, crispy baatis (wheat dough balls baked in clay ovens), spicy dal (lentil curry), and churma (sweetened crushed wheat with ghee). Smoky, hearty, and utterly indulgent with ghee flowing over everything.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originated as staple food for Rajput warriors and travelers in ancient Rajputana. The baatis were convenient for long journeys and could be preserved in scorching desert weather. Traditionally prepared in clay ovens or over charcoal, the smoky aroma elevates the whole experience. Warriors needed calorie-dense food that wouldn't spoil - hence the hard-baked baatis and protein-rich dal. The churma (sweet component) provided quick energy.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Krishna Dal Bati Restro (Krishna Special Thali ‚Çπ399 - authentic with 'loads of ghee' and 'out of this world' churma, includes Besan Gatte ka Saag, chutneys, chaas, papad), Santosh Dining Hall/New Santosh Bhojnalaya (famous among locals for the special taste), Natraj Dining Hall (unlimited vegetarian Rajasthani thali), Udaipur Traditional Restaurant (live music and lakeshore views with sunset over Lake Pichola).

hero_dishes.name: Laal Maas (Red Meat Curry)
hero_dishes.description: Fiery red mutton curry that gets its intense color from Mathania red chilies. The 'red meat' is swimming in a spicy, rich gravy with yogurt, garlic, and aromatic spices. Not for the faint-hearted - this is warrior food.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional Rajput dish originally cooked with wild game (deer, boar) hunted in royal forests. The intense red chili marinade both preserved the meat in desert heat and celebrated the warrior spirit. Rajput warriors prized bold, assertive flavors. Modern versions use mutton but maintain the fierce spice level.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Rajasthani restaurants throughout Udaipur, Jaajam Restaurant (4.9‚≠ê rated on Google/Zomato/TripAdvisor, uses traditional recipes and locally sourced spices), upscale heritage hotels.

hero_dishes.name: Gatte ki Sabzi
hero_dishes.description: Gram flour (besan) dumplings cooked in spiced yogurt curry. The gatte have a unique, slightly chewy texture and the tangy curry is complex with fenugreek, turmeric, and warming spices.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Rajasthan's desert climate meant fresh vegetables were scarce historically. Cooks developed ingenious vegetarian dishes using shelf-stable ingredients like gram flour and dried spices. Gatte ki sabzi shows the creativity born from scarcity - transforming simple chickpea flour into a beloved dish.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Krishna Dal Bati Restro (included in their thali as Besan Gatte ka Saag), Santosh Dining Hall, traditional Rajasthani thali restaurants, heritage hotels.

hero_dishes.name: Ker Sangri
hero_dishes.description: Desert beans (sangri) and berries (ker) cooked with spices - a uniquely Rajasthani dish using indigenous desert ingredients. Tangy, slightly sour, with earthy flavors.
hero_dishes.origin_story: These wild desert plants thrive in Rajasthan's harsh Thar Desert where little else grows. For centuries, locals foraged ker berries and sangri beans, drying them for year-round use. This dish represents adaptation to one of India's most challenging environments.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Authentic Rajasthani restaurants, heritage properties, traditional thali meals.

hero_dishes.name: Pyaaz Kachori & Mirchi Vada
hero_dishes.description: Deep-fried snacks: kachori stuffed with spicy onion filling, mirchi vada with green chilies dipped in gram flour batter. Crispy, spicy, addictive street food.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Classic Rajasthani street snacks that evolved from the state's frying traditions (preserving food in ghee/oil). Perfect with masala chai during monsoons or winter mornings. These snacks are Udaipur's answer to fast food - but infinitely more flavorful.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors throughout Udaipur, especially Chauraha Road (famous for kachori with masala chai), local tea stalls, JBM (kulhad coffee place), Vinod Coffeehouse area.

signature_drinks.name: Masala Chai (Spiced Tea)
signature_drinks.description: Black tea boiled with milk, sugar, and aromatic spices (cardamom, ginger, cinnamon, cloves). Rich, sweet, spicy, and deeply comforting.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Morning ritual and afternoon refreshment. Locals sip chai multiple times daily at tapris (tea stalls), often with kachori or samosas. The perfect accompaniment to street food. Small glasses, served steaming hot, drunk slowly while chatting.

signature_drinks.name: Kulhad Chai/Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Tea or coffee served in kulhad (earthen clay cups) that add a beautiful rustic, smoky flavor to the drink. The clay is porous and slightly cools the beverage while imparting earthy notes.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Increasingly popular nostalgic drinking vessel. Vinod Coffeehouse near Fateh Sagar Lake serves kulhad tea and coffee with lake views. JBM offers kulhad coffee - the smoky clay flavor infused with aromatic coffee beans creates 'magical' taste. After drinking, the clay cup is traditionally smashed (biodegradable, returns to earth).

signature_drinks.name: Chaas (Buttermilk)
signature_drinks.description: Salted, spiced buttermilk made from yogurt, often flavored with cumin, mint, and coriander. Pale white, slightly sour, refreshing.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Essential with heavy Rajasthani meals like Dal Baati Churma (included in traditional thalis). The tangy, cooling chaas aids digestion and balances rich, ghee-heavy foods. Drunk during meals, not after.

signature_drinks.name: Jaljeera
signature_drinks.description: Tangy, savory drink made with cumin, mint, tamarind, black salt, and chili. Dark brown color, intensely flavorful, slightly spicy.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Digestive and cooling drink, especially popular in Rajasthan's hot climate. Drunk before meals as an appetizer or with snacks. The black salt and cumin aid digestion.

signature_drinks.name: Lassi
signature_drinks.description: Sweet or salted yogurt drink, thick and creamy. Sometimes flavored with rose water, saffron, or mango.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sweet lassi is dessert in a glass - thick enough to eat with a spoon. Salted lassi is refreshing with meals. Particularly popular in summer to beat Rajasthan's intense heat.

food_culture_notes: Rajasthani cuisine developed to cope with desert scarcity - shelf-stable ingredients, minimal water, high-calorie foods
Ghee (clarified butter) is used lavishly - not just for flavor but as a sign of prosperity and hospitality
Vegetarianism is dominant in Udaipur due to Rajput and Marwari traditions, but Laal Maas shows the warrior meat-eating heritage
Thalis (unlimited platters) are the traditional way to eat - servers keep refilling until you're stuffed
Clay oven (tandoor) cooking and charcoal preparation add essential smoky flavors to baatis
Dal Baati Churma represents the Rajasthani meal philosophy: savory, spicy, and sweet all in one
Street food culture is vibrant - kachoris, mirchi vadas, samosas with chai at roadside stalls
Dining with Lake Pichola views is quintessential Udaipur - sunset meals at heritage restaurants
Local spices are point of pride - Mathania red chilies, wild desert ingredients like ker and sangri
Kulhad (clay cup) culture is making a comeback - eco-friendly and adds unique flavor
Traditional recipes at places like Krishna Dal Bati and Santosh Bhojnalaya are what locals actually eat
Heritage hotel restaurants offer royal Rajasthani cuisine, but local dining halls serve authentic daily food
Chaas (buttermilk) and jaljeera are essential for digesting rich, ghee-heavy Rajasthani meals
